articles.title: The Moon is rusting — thanks to ‘wind’ blown all the way from Earth
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 22 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03051-2Lunar minerals generate the rust mineral hematite when bombarded with high-energy oxygen particles, experiments show.
articles.content:
A stream of charged particles that blows from Earth (foreground) to the Moon could account for the rust compounds found in lunar soils. Credit: Tetra Images/Alamy

The Moon is rusting – and it’s Earth’s fault.

Scientists have found that oxygen particles blown from Earth to the Moon can turn lunar minerals into hematite, also known as rust1. The discovery adds to researchers’ growing understanding of the deep interconnection between Earth and the Moon — and shows how the Moon keeps a geological record of those interactions, says Ziliang Jin, a planetary scientist at Macau University of Science and Technology in China. He and his colleagues reported their findings earlier this month in Geophysical Research Letters.

Most of the time, both Earth and the Moon are bathed in a stream of charged particles emanating from the Sun. But for around five days each month, Earth passes between the Sun and the Moon, blocking most of the flood of solar particles. During that time, the Moon is exposed mainly to particles that had been part of Earth’s atmosphere before blowing into space — a phenomenon known as Earth wind.

That wind contains ions of various elements, including hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen. When those charged particles hit the Moon, they can implant themselves into the upper layers of lunar soil2 and trigger chemical reactions.

In 2020, scientists reported that India’s Chandrayaan-1 mission had spotted hematite near the Moon’s poles3. Hematite is an iron-rich mineral that can form when rocks react with water and oxygen. But the Moon’s chemical environment isn’t conducive to the presence of oxygen, meaning that the oxygen for the hematite might have arrived from somewhere else. The 2020 paper’s authors proposed that it might have arrived in the Earth wind.

Experimental support

Jin and his colleagues decided to test that idea in the laboratory. They simulated the Earth wind by accelerating hydrogen and oxygen ions to high energies. They then sent the ions whizzing into single crystals of iron-rich minerals that are known to exist on the Moon.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery explaining the presence of rust on the Moon caused by charged oxygen particles from Earth. This finding enhances understanding of Earth-Moon interactions and the lunar environment, representing a meaningful breakthrough in planetary science with broad implications for space research.
articles.personality_title: Earth’s wind causes rust to form on the Moon
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The Moon has patches of rust called hematite, which surprised scientists because rust usually needs oxygen and water to form. The Moon’s environment doesn’t have much oxygen, so researchers wondered where it came from.

**What happened** – Scientists discovered that charged oxygen particles blow from Earth to the Moon in a stream called Earth wind. Every month, for about five days, Earth blocks the Sun’s particles, letting this Earth wind reach the Moon. In experiments, researchers shot oxygen and hydrogen ions at minerals like those on the Moon and saw rust form.

**Impact** – This discovery explains how rust can exist on the Moon without water or oxygen there naturally. It shows Earth and the Moon are connected by more than just gravity — Earth’s atmosphere actually sends particles to the Moon, changing its surface. This helps scientists better understand how planets and moons affect each other.

**What's next step** – Researchers will study how Earth wind changes the Moon’s surface over time and its effects on other elements. Future space missions might measure Earth wind directly on the Moon to learn more about this connection.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Charged oxygen particles from Earth’s atmosphere create rust on the Moon, revealing a surprising link between the two bodies.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le vent de la Terre fait rouiller la Lune
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Lune présente des taches de rouille appelées hématite, ce qui a surpris les scientifiques car la rouille a besoin d’oxygène et d’eau pour se former. L’environnement lunaire contient peu d’oxygène, donc les chercheurs se demandaient d’où il venait.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des scientifiques ont découvert que des particules chargées d’oxygène soufflent de la Terre vers la Lune dans un flux appelé vent terrestre. Chaque mois, pendant environ cinq jours, la Terre bloque les particules du Soleil, laissant ce vent terrestre atteindre la Lune. Dans des expériences, les chercheurs ont projeté des ions d’oxygène et d’hydrogène sur des minéraux similaires à ceux de la Lune et ont observé la formation de rouille.

**Impact** – Cette découverte explique comment la rouille peut exister sur la Lune sans eau ni oxygène naturel. Elle montre que la Terre et la Lune sont reliées par plus que la gravité : l’atmosphère terrestre envoie en fait des particules vers la Lune, modifiant sa surface. Cela aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre comment les planètes et leurs lunes s’influencent.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont étudier comment le vent terrestre modifie la surface lunaire avec le temps et ses effets sur d’autres éléments. Les futures missions spatiales pourraient mesurer directement le vent terrestre sur la Lune pour en savoir plus.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des particules chargées d’oxygène provenant de l’atmosphère terrestre créent de la rouille sur la Lune, révélant un lien surprenant entre les deux corps.
articles.personality_title_es: El viento de la Tierra causa óxido en la Luna
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Luna tiene manchas de óxido llamadas hematita, lo que sorprendió a los científicos porque el óxido necesita oxígeno y agua para formarse. El ambiente lunar tiene poco oxígeno, así que los investigadores se preguntaban de dónde venía.

**Qué pasó** – Científicos descubrieron que partículas cargadas de oxígeno viajan desde la Tierra hacia la Luna en un flujo llamado viento terrestre. Cada mes, durante unos cinco días, la Tierra bloquea las partículas del Sol, dejando que este viento llegue a la Luna. En experimentos, los investigadores dispararon iones de oxígeno e hidrógeno a minerales similares a los lunares y vieron que se formaba óxido.

**Impacto** – Este hallazgo explica cómo puede haber óxido en la Luna sin agua ni oxígeno natural. Muestra que la Tierra y la Luna están conectadas por algo más que la gravedad: la atmósfera terrestre envía partículas que cambian la superficie lunar. Esto ayuda a entender mejor cómo planetas y lunas se afectan entre sí.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos estudiarán cómo el viento terrestre cambia la superficie lunar con el tiempo y sus efectos en otros elementos. Las futuras misiones espaciales podrían medir el viento terrestre directamente en la Luna para aprender más.

**Resumen en una frase** – Partículas cargadas de oxígeno de la atmósfera terrestre crean óxido en la Luna, mostrando una conexión inesperada entre ambos cuerpos.

articles.title: Venus has lava tubes, and they're weird
articles.summary: It has been suggested that lava tubes - underground tunnels carved out by molten rock - might be on Venus, and now we have direct evidence that this is the case
articles.content:
It has been suggested that lava tubes - underground tunnels carved out by molten rock - might be on Venus, and now we have direct evidence that this is the case

We are learning more about Venus, the hot, high-pressure planet JSC/NASA

We now know for sure that massive underground tunnels, carved by lava, exist on Venus – and they are surprisingly wide and different from those on any other planet.

It is uncontroversial that lava tubes – underground tunnels carved out by molten rock – exist on Earth, the moon and Mars. Smaller planets with low gravity tend to form more cavernous tubes, in part because the rock walls are less likely to collapse with weaker gravity. On the moon, for instance, the tubes are so large that scientists have proposed using them as live-in shelters for astronauts, providing shielding from the harsh solar wind.

Scientists had seen hints of these lava tubes on Venus, from holes and pits that appear to have formed on its surface, but it was unclear whether these were caused by lava tubes beneath them or by other geological processes, such as from an active fault line.

Now, Barbara De Toffoli at the University of Padova in Italy and her colleagues have found direct evidence of lava tubes on Venus. They also appear to be surprisingly wide and of a comparable volume to those on the moon, despite Venus being more like Earth in terms of its mass and gravity.

“Earth lava tubes have smaller volumes, Mars tubes have slightly bigger volumes, and then the moon’s tubes have even bigger volumes – and then there’s Venus, completely disrupting this trend, displaying very, very big tube volumes,” De Toffoli told the Europlanet Science Congress in Helsinki, Finland, earlier this month. “This is already giving away the fact that there’s likely something more on Venus playing a significant role.”

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Lost in Space-Time Untangle mind-bending physics, maths and the weirdness of reality with our monthly, special-guest-written newsletter. Sign up to newsletter

Using radar and mapping data from past missions, De Toffoli and her team analysed how these pits lined up and were arranged near large volcanoes. They found four clear examples that didn’t have any alternative geological explanation, like tectonic activity. The pits also lined up with the steepest part of the volcanoes’ slopes, which is the direction the lava would have travelled, and the ratio of their depth and width was consistent with other known lava tubes.

The tubes’ unexpected size, in particular their width, suggests that the extreme Venusian environment, which is very hot and high pressure, might affect how molten rock moves under its surface, said De Toffoli, and isn’t just dependent on gravity like lava tubes on other planets. “Due to the very high pressure, there’s an overall flattening out of the tubes, instead of having a very intense erosion at the floor that usually happens on other planets.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery of large lava tubes on Venus, providing new insights into planetary geology and expanding our understanding of Venus's environment. This has broad scientific significance and potential implications for future space exploration, fulfilling criteria for inspiring good news in the space category.
articles.personality_title: Scientists confirm giant lava tubes on Venus unlike any seen before
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Lava tubes are tunnels underground formed by flowing molten rock. They exist on Earth, the Moon, and Mars, usually larger on smaller planets with low gravity. Before, scientists only guessed similar tunnels might be on Venus.

**What happened** – A team led by Barbara De Toffoli from the University of Padova used radar and mapping data from past space missions to find clear proof of lava tubes on Venus. These tubes are very wide, similar in size to those on the Moon, even though Venus has gravity closer to Earth’s.

**Impact** – This discovery is important because Venus’s lava tubes break the usual pattern where bigger tubes are found on smaller planets. The planet’s high heat and pressure seem to change how lava flows underground, making these tunnels unusually wide. This helps scientists better understand Venus’s geology and how extreme conditions affect volcanic activity.

**What’s next step** – Researchers will study these lava tubes more closely to learn how Venus’s environment shapes underground lava flows. This could also guide future missions to Venus, possibly using these tunnels to explore or shelter equipment.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Scientists have found very wide lava tubes on Venus, showing that its extreme conditions create underground tunnels unlike those on any other planet.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques confirment l’existence de gigantesques tunnels de lave sur Vénus, uniques en leur genre
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les tunnels de lave sont des galeries souterraines formées par de la roche en fusion. Ils existent sur Terre, la Lune et Mars, généralement plus grands sur les planètes plus petites avec une faible gravité. Avant, les scientifiques supposaient seulement que de tels tunnels pourraient exister sur Vénus.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une équipe dirigée par Barbara De Toffoli de l’Université de Padoue a utilisé des données radar et cartographiques de missions spatiales passées pour trouver une preuve claire de tunnels de lave sur Vénus. Ces tunnels sont très larges, de taille comparable à ceux de la Lune, même si la gravité de Vénus est proche de celle de la Terre.

**Impact** – Cette découverte est importante car les tunnels de lave de Vénus ne suivent pas la tendance habituelle où les plus grands tunnels se trouvent sur les planètes plus petites. La chaleur et la pression extrêmes de Vénus semblent modifier la façon dont la lave coule sous terre, rendant ces tunnels exceptionnellement larges. Cela aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre la géologie de Vénus et l’effet des conditions extrêmes sur l’activité volcanique.

**Prochaine étape** – Les chercheurs vont étudier ces tunnels de lave plus en détail pour comprendre comment l’environnement de Vénus influence les coulées souterraines. Cela pourrait aussi guider de futures missions vers Vénus, utilisant peut-être ces tunnels pour explorer ou protéger du matériel.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Les scientifiques ont découvert des tunnels de lave très larges sur Vénus, montrant que ses conditions extrêmes créent des galeries souterraines uniques parmi les planètes.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos confirman gigantescos tubos de lava en Venus, únicos en su tipo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los tubos de lava son túneles subterráneos formados por roca fundida. Existen en la Tierra, la Luna y Marte, generalmente son más grandes en planetas pequeños con baja gravedad. Antes, los científicos solo sospechaban que podrían existir tubos similares en Venus.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo liderado por Barbara De Toffoli de la Universidad de Padua usó datos de radar y mapas de misiones espaciales anteriores para encontrar pruebas claras de tubos de lava en Venus. Estos tubos son muy anchos, de tamaño parecido a los de la Luna, aunque Venus tiene una gravedad más parecida a la Tierra.

**Impacto** – Este descubrimiento es importante porque los tubos de lava de Venus rompen la regla de que los tubos más grandes están en planetas más pequeños. El calor y la presión extremas en Venus parecen cambiar cómo fluye la lava bajo tierra, haciendo estos túneles inusualmente anchos. Esto ayuda a los científicos a entender mejor la geología de Venus y cómo las condiciones extremas afectan la actividad volcánica.

**Próximo paso** – Los investigadores estudiarán estos tubos de lava con más detalle para aprender cómo el ambiente de Venus influye en los flujos subterráneos de lava. Esto también podría ayudar a futuras misiones a Venus, usando estos túneles para explorar o proteger equipos.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los científicos han encontrado tubos de lava muy anchos en Venus, mostrando que sus condiciones extremas crean túneles subterráneos diferentes a los de cualquier otro planeta.
